title-group.article-title: Practical Design of Minimum Induced Loss Propellers

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright Â© Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc., 1980

abstract.p: An efficient procedure, which may be adapted to pocket calculators, has been developed to determine the geometry of minimum induced loss propellers matched to a specified operating point characterized by disc loading, advance ratio, and number of blades. Consistent procedures are described to account for the effects of arbitrary geometry, off design point operation, and propeller body interaction. These procedures are utilized by George Succi in a companion paper on the design of quiet propellers.

ref.mixed-citation: Betz, Albert: "Schraubenpropeller mit geringstem Energieverlust; " and Prandtl, Ludwig: appendix for the above. Goettinger Nachrichten, 1919. Reprinted 1927 in "Vier Abhandlungen zur Hydrodynamik und Aerodynamik," also at Goettingen.
Glauer t, Herman: "The Elements of Aerofoil and Airscrew Theory;" Cambridge University Press, 1926.
Glauert, Herman: Article on "Air- plane Propellers," Div. I, Vol. IV of "Aerodynamic Theory," pp 169-360. Springer Verlag, 1934. Also photo offset editions by Durand Reprinting Committee and Dover.
Goldstein, Sidney: "On the Vortex Theory of Screw Propellers;" Proc. of the Royal Society (A) 123, 440, 1929.
Larrabee, E. Eugene; and Phillips, W. Hewitt: "A Program to Design Pro- pellers;" to be published in the Hewlitt Packard "Keyboard" magazine.
Foley, William M. : "From daVinci to the Present -A Review of Airscrew Theory for Helicopters, Propellers, Windmills and Engines;" AIAA Paper 76-367.
Koning, C. : "Influence of the Pro- peller on Other Parts of the Air- plane Structure;" Div. M, Vol. IV of "Aerodynamic Theory," pp 365-367; [see (3) above].
